snippet: More than 110,000 children have had to find new ways to class since most New York City school bus drivers walked out, and none have been more profoundly affected than those with special needs.
abstract: More than 110,000 New York City school children have had to find alternate ways to class since the beginning of strike by school bus drivers; problem is particularly devastating for special needs children and their parents, who tend to travel longest distances to school.

byline.contributor: Marc Santora, Kyle Spencer and Julie Turkewitz contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: More than 110,000 children have had to find new ways to class since most New York City school bus drivers walked out, and none have been more profoundly affected than those with special needs.

headline.seo: School Bus Strike Poses Challenge for Special-Needs Students
headline.main: With Bus Strike, Fragile Students Face Hard Trips
headline.print_headline: With Bus Strike, Fragile Students Face Hard Trips
